title: Parallel iteration with zip() and enumerate(): iterate multiple sequences with an index
content:
After you know basic loops, a very useful moderate technique is **parallel iteration**: walking through two or more sequences at the same time. The built-ins `zip()` and `enumerate()` are common tools for this.

---
## 1) zip(): pair items by position

```python
names = ["Ana", "Ben", "Kai"]
scores = [10, 25, 18]

for name, score in zip(names, scores):
    print(name, "scored", score)
```

If the lists have different lengths, `zip` stops at the shortest.

```python
names = ["Ana", "Ben", "Kai"]
scores = [10, 25]

for name, score in zip(names, scores):
    print(name, score)
# prints only Ana/Ben
```

---
## 2) enumerate(): add an index

```python
items = ["a", "b", "c"]
for i, v in enumerate(items):
    print(i, v)
```

Start indexing from 1:

```python
for i, v in enumerate(items, start=1):
    print(i, v)
```

---
## 3) Combine enumerate + zip: index + paired values

```python
names = ["Ana", "Ben", "Kai"]
scores = [10, 25, 18]

for i, (name, score) in enumerate(zip(names, scores), start=1):
    print(i, name, score)
```

---
## 4) A more realistic example: align columns and compute totals

```python
products = ["pen", "notebook", "tape"]
prices = [1.50, 3.00, 2.25]
qty = [2, 1, 3]

grand = 0.0
for i, (p, price, q) in enumerate(zip(products, prices, qty), start=1):
    line = price * q
    grand += line
    print(i, p, "line=", line)

print("grand=", grand)
```

---
## 5) Practice: detect mismatched lists early (simple check)
Sometimes you *want* to ensure lengths match.

```python
if len(products) != len(prices) or len(prices) != len(qty):
    print("length mismatch")
else:
    for p, price, q in zip(products, prices, qty):
        print(p, price, q)
```
